position.translation[0].definitions[0].d: the way someone is standing, sitting, or lying
position.translation[0].definitions[0].e: Frankie shifted his position so that his knees would not become cramped.
I struggled up into a sitting position.
position.translation[0].definitions[1].d: the situation that someone is in, especially when this affects what they can and cannot do
position.translation[0].definitions[1].e: I’m not sure what I would do if I were in your position.
You’re putting me in rather a difficult position.
Next week we will be in a much better position to comment.
be in a position to do something
She is in the enviable position of having three job offers.
be in the position of doing something
position.translation[0].definitions[2].d: the place where someone or something is, especially in relation to other objects and places
position.translation[0].definitions[2].e: Our hotel was in a superb central position near St Mark’s Square.
the strategic position (=useful or important position) of Egypt in relation to the Arabian peninsula
the position of the sun in the sky
position.translation[0].definitions[3].d: the place where someone or something is needed or supposed to be
position.translation[0].definitions[3].e: He pulled the ladder into position.
All parking signs have now been placed in position.
position.translation[0].definitions[4].d: the direction in which an object is pointing
position.translation[0].definitions[4].e: She turned the switch to the ‘on’ position.
Make sure the container remains in an upright position.
position.translation[0].definitions[5].d: an opinion or judgment on a particular subject, especially the official opinion of a government, a political party, or someone in authority
position.translation[0].definitions[5].e: The principal took the position that the students didn’t need music classes.
I hope you’ll reconsider your position.
What’s the party’s position on tax reform?
position.translation[0].definitions[6].e: Bill took up his new position as Works Director in October.
She has held the position of Chief Financial Officer since 1992.
Bruce is thinking of applying for the position.
I’m sorry, the position has been filled (=someone has been found to do the job).
position.translation[0].definitions[7].d: someone’s or something’s level, authority, or importance in a society or organization
position.translation[0].definitions[7].n: abuse your position as something (=use your authority wrongly)
position.translation[0].definitions[7].e: As a priest, he was in a position of trust.
Many of his supporters used their positions of power for personal advantage.
the position of women in society
position.translation[0].definitions[8].d: the place of someone or something in a race or competition in relation to the other people or things
position.translation[0].definitions[9].d: the area where someone plays in a sport, or the type of actions they are responsible for doing
a place where an army has put soldiers, guns etc
an attack on the enemy positions
position.translation[0].note_box[0].head: – Meaning 1: the way someone is standing, sitting, or lying
position.translation[0].note_box[0].sect: She wriggled into a more comfortable position.
My foot was in an awkward position.
The priest rose from his kneeling position by the bed.
I crawled into my bed and curled up in a foetal position.
He shifted his position to get a better view of the stage.
She pulled herself into a sitting position.
The patient should adopt this position for five minutes every half hour.
Pull in your tummy muscles and hold that position.
position.translation[0].note_box[1].head: – Meaning 2: the situation that someone is in, especially when this affects what they can and cannot do
position.translation[0].note_box[1].sect: the same position
A lot of people are in the same position.
a similar position
You can ask to be put in contact with others in a similar position.
a strong/good position
A victory tonight will put them in a very strong position to win the cup.
a unique position
Their close knowledge of the area places them in a unique position to advise on social policy.
a difficult/awkward position
I was in the difficult position of having to choose between them.
an enviable position
He is in the enviable position of not needing to work.
an impossible position
She was furious with Guy for putting her in such an impossible position.
a weak position
Someone who is desperate to sell their house is in a weak position.
a vulnerable position
Today we are in the vulnerable position of producing barely half our own food.
the present/current position
The following statistics indicate the present position.
the legal position
The legal position is far from clear.
somebody’s financial position
Has your financial position changed recently?
a bargaining/negotiating position
The new law has strengthened workers' bargaining position.
be in a strong/weak etc position
We are in a good position to help.
find yourself in a similar/awkward etc position
The refugee organizations now found themselves in a difficult position.
reach a position
It has taken two years to reach the position we are now in.
put/place somebody in a good/awkward etc position
I'm sorry if I put you in an awkward position.
strengthen somebody’s position
People said that he used the conflict to strengthen his own position.
weaken somebody’s position
The prime minister's position had been weakened by allegations of financial mismanagement.
somebody’s position improves
By March, the Democrats' position had improved.
a position of strength
By now they were negotiating from a position of strength.
position.translation[0].note_box[2].head: – Meaning 6: an opinion or judgment on a particular subject, especially the official opinion of a government, a political party, or someone in authority
position.translation[0].note_box[2].sect: We take the position that these changes are to be welcomed.
In 1898, the Church adopted its current position.
Since then, the party has changed its position.
The UN Secretary General urged the US to reconsider its position.
Each of the next three speakers defended a different position.
This was the French government’s official position.
Few people hold this extreme position today.
They took a middle position, favouring decentralization but with some controls.
The US claimed that Jordan had abandoned its neutral position and sided with Iraq.
position.translation[0].note_box[3].head: – Meaning 7: a job
position.translation[0].note_box[3].sect: hold a position
She had previously held a senior position in another school.
apply for a position
I decided to apply for the position of head teacher.
take up a position
Woods took up a new position as managing director of a company in Belfast.
leave a position
He left his position as Chief Conductor of the Moscow Radio Symphony Orchestra.
resign from a position
She has resigned from her position as department secretary.
offer somebody a position
They offered me the position of store manager.
fill a position
We are now seeking to fill some key positions in the company.
a senior position
Decision making is done by managers holding the most senior positions.
a junior position
I left school and was offered a junior position in a bank.
a permanent/temporary position
It's a temporary position initially, for six months.
an official position
He has no official position in the government.
position.translation[0].note_box[4].head: – Meaning 8: someone’s or something’s level, authority, or importance in a society or organization
position.translation[0].note_box[4].sect: a position of power/authority
Many used their positions of power for personal advantage.
a position of influence
The media have an unrivalled position of influence.
a position of trust
As a church leader, he was in a position of trust.
a position of responsibility
Did you hold any positions of responsibility at school or university?
a position of leadership
She had risen to a position of leadership.
a privileged position
The public expects the Royal Family to earn its privileged position.
an influential position
It's useful if you have friends in influential positions.
a powerful position
Many leaders from that period are still in powerful positions in government.
a dominant position
The firm achieved a dominant position in the world market.
occupy a position
Those who occupy positions of power do not want democracy.
maintain a position
High-status groups do all they can to maintain their positions.
use your position
She can now use her position to do some good.
abuse your position
He abused his position as a doctor.
position.translation[0].note_box[5].sect: describing someone’s position in an organization
senior
used about someone who has an important position in an organization. Senior can also be used about someone who has a higher position than you in an organization
a senior executive
She’s a senior partner in a law firm.
She is senior to me.
chief
used, especially in job titles, about someone who has the most important or one of the most important positions in an organization
Carole is the company’s chief financial officer.
He’s the chief economist at Hangseng Bank.
high-ranking
used about someone who has a high position in an organization such as the government, the army, or the police
high-ranking government officials
a high-ranking police officer
top
used about someone who is very good, important, or successful in their job
a top lawyer
He’s one of the president’s top aides.
top diplomats
junior
used about someone who has a low position in an organization. Junior can also be used about someone who has a lower position than you in an organization
a junior clerk
a junior doctor
His role as naval officer was junior to Nelson.
assistant
an assistant manager, director, editor etc has a position just below a manager etc
He’s an assistant professor of neurology at Harvard University.
She became assistant director at the Belgrade Theatre.
position.translation[1].definitions[0].d: to carefully put something in a particular position
position.translation[1].definitions[0].e: Position the cursor before the letter you want to delete.
I positioned myself where I could see the door.
position.translation[2].definitions[0].d: the situation that a person or organization is in, or the situation concerning a particular subject
position.translation[2].definitions[0].e: The company is in a strong financial position, with more than $7 million in cash and no short-term debt.
The investment would weaken the company’s competitive position.
The new legislation puts the unions in a difficult position.
What’s the present position with regard to import restrictions?
position.translation[2].definitions[1].d: to be able to do something because you have the ability, money, or power to do it
position.translation[2].definitions[1].e: We will refund your money when we are in a position to do so.
position.translation[2].definitions[2].d: to try to get an advantage over other people who are all trying to succeed in the same activity
position.translation[2].definitions[2].e: US advertising agencies are jostling for position in Eastern Europe.
position.translation[2].definitions[3].d: the level or rank someone or something has in society or in an organization
position.translation[2].definitions[3].e: He was a doctor with a respectable position in society.
We need more women in positions of authority and influence in television.
Financial institutions are in a unique position of trust when handling funds belonging to the public.
He did not want to be accused of abusing his position (=using his authority wrongly).
position.translation[2].definitions[4].d: a job, especially an important one
position.translation[2].definitions[4].e: She is retiring from her position as chief executive.
Twelve people applied for the position (=asked to have the job).
He is filling a position (=taking a job) that has been vacant since July.
He has been offered amanagement position in Cairo.
He is older than most executives in their first senior position (=important job) abroad.
position.translation[2].definitions[5].d: someone’s opinion or judgement on something
position.translation[2].definitions[5].e: What’s your position on using freelance staff?
position.translation[2].definitions[6].d: an investment in something, or the amount invested
position.translation[2].definitions[6].e: The family has a recent history of buying positions of over 5% in public companies.
It said it will take a 10% equity position (=buy 10% of the shares) in the company.
After we have earned a modest profit, we will simply cash our position out (=sell our investment).
position.translation[3].definitions[0].d: if you position yourself in a particular way, or if something positions you in that way, you are prepared for a situation that you want to happen or think is going to happen
position.translation[3].definitions[0].e: It has been working to position itself as a seller of group health insurance to major corporations.
The company’s restructuring has positioned it to compete more effectively.
position.translation[3].definitions[1].d: if a company positions a product in a particular way, it tries to get people to think about it in that way in relation to the company’s other products and to competing products
position.translation[3].definitions[1].e: The trend over the past decade has been to position pizza as a health food.
We’re trying to position the product toward younger buyers.
